mainEntity.name: What is Dual Licensing in open source monetization?

acceptedAnswer.text: Dual licensing involves offering an open source project under two licenses: a free open source license and a paid commercial license. This allows businesses to use the free version under specific terms or pay for additional enterprise functionalities and support.

mainEntity.name: How can paid support or consulting help monetize an open source project?

acceptedAnswer.text: Providing paid professional services like installation, troubleshooting, maintenance, and consulting can help project maintainers capitalize on their expertise while assisting organizations to use or customize the software.

mainEntity.name: What platforms can be used for sponsorships and donations?

acceptedAnswer.text: Platforms like GitHub Sponsors, Open Collective, and Patreon allow open source maintainers to collect donations or sponsorships from individuals and organizations benefiting from their work.

mainEntity.name: What is the Freemium model in open source?

acceptedAnswer.text: The freemium model provides a free version of the software while charging users for premium features, advanced services, or integrations. This approach allows developers to attract a large user base while generating revenue from paid enhancements.

mainEntity.name: How can merchandising help monetize open source projects?

acceptedAnswer.text: Popular projects with a large community can sell branded merchandise such as T-shirts, stickers, and mugs to generate additional revenue while fostering community engagement.

mainEntity.name: How does selling certifications or training generate income?

acceptedAnswer.text: Offering certifications or training programs helps developers and organizations enhance their expertise in using an open source project. It also allows maintainers to monetize by providing workshops, tutorials, or certification exams.

mainEntity.name: What is SaaS and how can it monetize open source projects?

acceptedAnswer.text: Turning open source software into a SaaS (Software as a Service) involves hosting and managing the software for customers, who pay for the convenience of a managed, ready-to-use implementation.
